comments.body: What you haven't tested is the module's ability to _change_ configuration as you have to verify and remove it. This is pretty simple... what commands would be issued if the `server` key changed? Or `source_int`? You should verify that each parameter issues the right command when it differs from the provided configuration. This can be individually, or all together, or in whatever grouping seems most applicable to your module.
Ok, I might have get it. I have updated the parameters under the functions to be different form the fixture as well as the `change`
Alright, but now you're not testing idempotence anymore. I would just add the original test back as a third test.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +59,63 @@        commands = []
        self.execute_module(changed=False, commands=commands)

    def test_ios_ntp_config(self):
        set_module_args(dict(
